department: Art of Africa and the Americas
description: blue and red wool; bird design with human face on chest; pair of serpents heads with bear (or human?) face between them below bird; iridescent buttons highlight center design and form geometric designs at top and sides
text: Artist and educator Marion Hunt Doig lends her contemporary perspective to the button blanket, a tradition that dates back to the early 1800s and the first contact between European fur traders and tribes on the Northwest Coast. First Nations artists obtained navy wool blankets through trade, adding red cloth and abalone shells to create family crests. Button blankets are worn at potlatches, gift-giving feasts that celebrate social milestones and chiefly status.
title: Button Blanket
